p: Underlying our research is the need to examine the social contract on which CSR rests ( Donaldson and Dunfee, 1994, 1999, 2000). If societyâ€™s expectations change, then CSR must as well or else it will face a perceived violation of the social contract. Pinkston and Carroll (1996) note that the demands that the public place on corporations do change; yet most of the research on CSR considers how the corporations themselves see their responsibilities or, at most, how their customers see their responsibilities (e.g., Mohr et al., 2001; Russell et al., 2016), and not how society more broadly views them. Alongside many others, we argue that because CSR is a social contract there is a need to understand not only what corporations and academics believe CSR to be, but also what society believes CSR to be and thus how it is operationalized in practice ( Sacconi, 2006). We do so in the particular realm of environmental responsibility.
